page.title: 14DRY STONE WALLING, WYKE AREA
page.content: In the area, the fences are a mixture of dry stone walls, hedges and fences. Jim Marsh of Elland, was a farmer who learned the art of dry stone walling as part of his daily work. He is now retired, but uses his skill repairing walls for local farmers. Knowing how and where to split the gritstone and sandstone is an art in itself. The wall has a base of 'footings', and is then built up in two faces with the fragments broken off from the larger rocks used as infil. Every couple of feet 'through' stones are inserted for stability and the wall completed with a row of capstones. Jim's secret for a strong, hardy wall is a wide base tapering to a narrow top.
